liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Lance "Buddy" Franklin, who last season became one of only five players to kick 1,000 VFL/AFL goals, is set to announce his retirement today. The 36-year-old is believed to have told his teammates of his retirement this morning, with the Sydney Swans scheduling a press conference for 3pm today. You can read more about this story here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Sydney Swans legend Lance Franklin to announce retirement

featuredLink.title: AFL legend Lance 'Buddy' Franklin set to announce retirement from game at age of 36

children.content: Lance "Buddy"
Franklin, who last season became one of only five players to kick 1,000 VFL/AFL goals, is set to announce his retirement today.
The 36-year-old is believed to have told his teammates of his retirement this morning, with the Sydney Swans scheduling a press conference for 3pm today.
You can read more about this story here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Defence Minister Richard Marles says evidence in the search for the MRH90 helicopter which crashed in Queensland on Friday shows there was a "catastrophic incident" and there is no hope four missing airmen will be found alive. The minister spoke with families of Captain Danniel Lyon, Lieutenant Maxwell Nugent, Warrant Officer Class Two Joseph Laycock and Corporal Alexander Naggs this morning. "The tragedies that have taken place in the Whitsundays have transferred from those being of search and rescue to an activity of recovery," he says. "We are all obviously left wondering naturally what happened. "For most, in our minds, in this moment, foremost, is the families of these four men and their teammates." Marles says the search and rescue mission has now shifted to a "an activity of recovery". You can follow the ongoing press conference in this story .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Defence officials say missing airmen involved in helicopter crash are presumed dead

props.alt: A white man in a suit speaking in front of an Australian flag

children.content: (ABC News)
Defence Minister Richard Marles says evidence in the search for the MRH90 helicopter which crashed in Queensland on Friday shows
there was a "catastrophic incident" and there is no hope four missing airmen will be found alive
The minister spoke with families of Captain Danniel Lyon, Lieutenant Maxwell Nugent, Warrant Officer Class Two Joseph Laycock and Corporal Alexander Naggs this morning.
"The tragedies that have taken place in the Whitsundays have transferred from those being of search and rescue to an activity of recovery," he says.
"We are all obviously left wondering naturally what happened.
"For most, in our minds, in this moment, foremost, is the families of these four men and their teammates."
Marles says the search and rescue mission has now shifted to a "an activity of recovery".
You can
follow the ongoing press conference in this story

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: New South Wales won't follow Victoria's lead in banning gas connections in new households despite NSW Premier Chris Minns conceding electricity is far cheaper. Victoria announced last week that all new residential properties and subdivisions which require a planning permit will only be powered by electricity from January 1. While NSW had been on the fence over the weekend, the premier has drawn a line through a similar gas ban this morning, AAP reports. "We're not pursuing that," he tells 2GB. The premier's call came a day after NSW Energy Minister Penny Sharpe said her office was still contemplating a gas ban. "We're not ruling it out all together but I've got to say it's not a priority," she told reporters on Sunday.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The NSW premier has ruled out a gas ban for new households

props.alt: A large pot with a lid and handles boiling on a gas stove

children.content: (Pexels: Oleg Magni)
New South Wales won't follow Victoria's lead in banning gas connections in new households
despite NSW Premier Chris Minns conceding electricity is far cheaper.
Victoria announced last week that all new residential properties and subdivisions which require a planning permit will only be powered by electricity from January 1.
While NSW had been on the fence over the weekend, the premier has drawn a line through a similar gas ban this morning, AAP reports.
"We're not pursuing that," he tells 2GB.
The premier's call came a day after NSW Energy Minister Penny Sharpe said her office was still contemplating a gas ban.
"We're not ruling it out all together but I've got to say it's not a priority," she told reporters on Sunday.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian dollar is a little stronger after some disappointing Chinese manufacturing data was released, which reinforced expectations that Beijing will have to pump more stimulus into its economy. The local currency had risen 0.4% to 66.74 US cents by 1:10pm AEST. But the Australian share market erased most of its early gains, with the ASX 200 flat at 7,406 points. China's manufacturing activity shrank for a fourth straight month in July (albeit at a slower pace), according to results of a factory survey published today by the country's National Bureau of Statistics. The official purchasing managers' index ( PMI ) was at 49.3 points this month (a slight improvement over the 49-point reading it scored in June). Any score below 50-points means the industry is contracting (while a score above 50 mean it's expanding). The world's second-largest economy grew at a slow pace in the June quarter, as demand remained weak at home and abroad, leading the Politburo - a top decision-making body of the ruling Communist Party - to describe economic recovery as "tortuous". Despite that, it was a strong day for Asian stock markets with the Nikkei, Shanghai Composite and Hang Seng rising by 1.5%, 0.6% and 1.5% respectively.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Aussie dollar rises, China's factory activity falls for fourth straight month

children.content: The Australian dollar is a little stronger after some disappointing Chinese manufacturing data was released, which reinforced expectations that Beijing will have to pump more stimulus into its economy.
The local currency had risen 0.4% to
66.74 US cents
by 1:10pm AEST.
But the Australian share market erased most of its early gains, with the
ASX 200 flat at 7,406 points.

China's manufacturing activity shrank for a fourth straight month in July (albeit at a slower pace), according to results of a factory survey published today by the country's National Bureau of Statistics.
The official purchasing managers' index (
PMI
) was at
49.3 points
this month (a slight improvement over the 49-point reading it scored in June).
Any score below 50-points means the industry is contracting (while a score above 50 mean it's expanding).

The world's second-largest economy grew at a slow pace in the June quarter, as demand remained weak at home and abroad, leading the Politburo - a top decision-making body of the ruling Communist Party - to describe economic recovery as "tortuous".
Despite that, it was a strong day for Asian stock markets with the
Nikkei, Shanghai Composite
and
Hang Seng
rising by 1.5%, 0.6% and 1.5% respectively.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: There's a big divide on what the Reserve Bank will do tomorrow — depending on whether you ask an economist, or pay attention to the market's pricing. The RBA is expected to lift rates once more by 0.25 percentage points on Tuesday, and pause for the rest of the year as inflation is still running well above the target, according to a slim majority of economists in a Reuters poll. Here's what Reuters is saying: Although the RBA has raised rates by a total of 400 basis points since May 2022, inflation was still running at 6% in the last quarter (double the upper end of the 2-3% target range). A record low unemployment rate and a rebound in house prices in Australia - one of the world's most expensive housing markets - suggests the RBA still needs to raise base borrowing costs. Most global central banks are inching closer to the end of an historic tightening campaign, including the US Federal Reserve, and economists also expect the RBA will be done soon. Thirty-six economists were surveyed by Reuters, in a poll taken on July 26-28. Over 55% of those economists forecast the RBA to raise its official cash rate by 25 basis points to 4.35%, the highest in nearly 12 years, at its August 1 meeting. The remaining 45% expected no change to the cash rate target. But financial markets were pricing in only a one in five chance of that happening. Among major local banks, Commonwealth Bank and Westpac expected a 25 basis points hike tomorrow, while ANZ and NAB predicted a pause.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Slim majority of economists in Reuters poll anticipating RBA rate hike tomorrow

children.content: There's a big divide on what the Reserve Bank will do tomorrow — depending on whether you ask an economist, or pay attention to the market's pricing.

The RBA is expected to lift rates once more by 0.25 percentage points on Tuesday, and pause for the rest of the year as inflation is still running well above the target, according to a slim majority of economists in a Reuters poll.
Here's what
Reuters
is saying:
Although the RBA has raised rates by a total of 400 basis points since May 2022, inflation was still running at 6% in the last quarter (double the upper end of the 2-3% target range).
A record low unemployment rate and a rebound in house prices in Australia - one of the world's most expensive housing markets - suggests the RBA still needs to raise base borrowing costs.
Most global central banks are inching closer to the end of an historic tightening campaign, including the US Federal Reserve, and economists also expect the RBA will be done soon.
Thirty-six economists were surveyed by Reuters, in a poll taken on July 26-28.
Over 55% of those economists forecast the RBA to raise its official cash rate by 25 basis points to 4.35%, the highest in nearly 12 years, at its August 1 meeting.
The remaining 45% expected no change to the cash rate target.
But financial markets were pricing in only a one in five chance of that happening.
Among major local banks, Commonwealth Bank and Westpac expected a 25 basis points hike tomorrow, while ANZ and NAB predicted a pause.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Origin Energy, which is set to be taken over by a Brookfield-led consortium, said revenue from its share of the Australia Pacific LNG project (APLNG) fell 12.3% in the fourth quarter, hurt by lower prices. Oil and liquefied natural gas (LNG) prices have fallen from their 2022 peaks as slower-than-expected economic growth in key consumer China and concerns about global economic prospects cloud the outlook for fuel demand. Australia's second-largest power producer said its share of revenue from APLNG — a joint venture with ConocoPhillips and Sinopec — fell to $611 million for the three months to June 30 (compared with $697 million a year earlier). Origin, which is nearing the conclusion of its $15.35 billion takeover by a consortium led by Canada's Brookfield, said the average realised price for LNG in the quarter was $US12.24 per metric million British thermal unit (mmBtu). It's a significant drop from the price it fetched for LNG a year earlier ($US14.24 per mmBtu). By 12:10pm AEST, Origin Energy's share price was flat at $8.52. - Reuters / ABC
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Origin Energy posts 12% drop in quarterly revenue from Australia Pacific LNG

children.content: Origin Energy, which is set to be taken over by a Brookfield-led consortium, said revenue from its share of the Australia Pacific LNG project (APLNG) fell 12.3% in the fourth quarter, hurt by lower prices.

Oil and liquefied natural gas (LNG) prices have fallen from their 2022 peaks as slower-than-expected economic growth in key consumer China and concerns about global economic prospects cloud the outlook for fuel demand.

Australia's second-largest power producer said its share of revenue from APLNG — a joint venture with ConocoPhillips and Sinopec — fell to $611 million for the three months to June 30 (compared with $697 million a year earlier).

Origin, which is nearing the conclusion of its $15.35 billion takeover by a consortium led by Canada's Brookfield, said the average realised price for LNG in the quarter was $US12.24 per metric million British thermal unit (mmBtu).
It's a significant drop from the price it fetched for LNG a year earlier ($US14.24 per mmBtu).
By 12:10pm AEST, Origin Energy's share price was flat at $8.52.
- Reuters / ABC
